title: How fast do earthquake shockwaves travel? - Quora

response.answer_text: The velocity of shockwaves is a non-linear effect, and varies as a function of several variables, some of which are the material properties of the medium in which the wave is propagating, and the others depend are the properties of the source. The theory of shockwaves is an extension of continuum mechanics beyond the elastic regime. The elastic regime is characterized by small and slow perturbations to an otherwise static system. Recall Hooke’s law: F = - k x. Hooke’s law is the lowest order contribution in a power series. Consider the example of a spring, which is the canonical example of a linear restoring force (i.e. Hookean behavior). Assuming the spring is built out of some infinitely strong material, the restoring force should grow indefinitely as the spring is extended to its maximum (finite) length, which is clearly not characterized by the linear -k x description. This example shows how materials will generally exhibit non-Hookean behavior in the large-displacement regime. This example demonstrates one of the many confounding factors that make a simple characterization of the velocity of shockwaves impossible. However, as shockwaves propagate away from a (finite) source, their amplitude will, in general, decay because of geometric attenuation. After some finite time, these waves will become small enough that we can treat them to a good approximation by Hooke’s law. Formally, we do not call these waves “shock waves,” as they are well-described by linear elasticity: we call them “acoustic waves.” In this case, a good characterization of velocity is possible based only on the local material properties of the Earth, which, over large enough distances, only depend on the radius from the Earth’s center. These velocities are well described in the “Preliminary Reference Earth Model.”

There are 2 types of waves that emerge from earthquakes: Body waves and surface waves. Body waves are faster and in turn are of two types: P & S waves. Earthquakes do not occur below 700km inside Earth, and most of them occur in the top 200km inside Earth. Here, P-waves are the fastest, and travel at around 7-8 km/s. S-waves travel at around 3-4 km/s. But the more disastrous surface waves travel even slower than S-waves.

There are multiple seismic waves in an earthquake, but there are two very important ones that will be covered. The primary waves are the first waves to arrive at a location. They tend to travel at 8 kilometers a second, or well over 26,000 kilometers per hour. The secondary waves can travel at nearly 5 kilometers per second, or 18,000 kilometers per hour. Shock waves are by definition non-linear waves in which energy piles up in a shock front caused by dispersion as the material is breaking due to the strength of the wave. So I’ll assume you instead mean compressional or P wave, the fastest of normal (linear) seismic waves. Compressional waves in the Earth’s crust travel 2 to 6 km/sec, with velocity generally increasing with depth. In water, 1.5 km/s, and in air, about 0.3 km/s. Most of the seismic wave energy, however, is in the slower shear waves and sometimes surface waves, which are mostly shear energy.

Earthquake waves usually compose of compressional waves, shear waves and surface waves and other long period standing waves (sometimes called normal modes). Different waves have different wave speeds in different materials. Typically in earth crust, the compressional waves propagate with 6.0 km/s, they become faster in earth mantle. Shear waves are slower than compressional waves. Surface waves are even slower and their speeds depend on their periods, in another words, they are dispersive.

Assuming that by earthquake shockwave compressional waves (P-waves) are meant, it must be told that the velocity of such waves, which are elastic waves, is strictly a function of the medium thru which they propagate. Usually in stiff crustal rocks Vp= 5 to 7 kms-1, although in fractured rocks the values are lower and they may be as low as 2 kms-1 in softer sediments.
See e.g. Seismic wave - Wikipedia P-waves are faster, up to 5000m/s in granite. S-waves about 60% of that.

I thought shock waves were like sound waves and traveled at different speeds in different mediums (faster in water than in air). But I thought, incorrectly, that shock waves were sound waves with much higher amplitudes. It is more complex than that, however, and shockwaves travel faster with higher amplitudes. Often they travel faster than the speed of sound.
There are three different EQ waves. P and S waves have speeds of 4.8 km/sec and about 3 km / sec respectively. Love and Rayleigh waves are slower than P and S waves.
It depends on where the epicenter is, including how deep, and the types of rocks between them, etc. There is no one answer.
